They're testing something called Sam's Club Now, that will open in Dallas next week. They told us about this back in June, and it's pretty much similar to what Amazon Go is doing. So, they're employing mobile checkout, camera-like systems for inventory management, and I guess, they're still playing catchup to Amazon at this point. Back to you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. Susan, thank you. We are watching markets today. We'll be watching you with a big rally expected at the opening of trading. Meanwhile, Brazil's next president, big story, conservative candidate Jair Bolsonaro is claiming victory this morning in his country's election. Joining us now is the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney. Good morning to you, Stu.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. Look, I don't think that the election of Jair Bolsonaro is going to have that much effect on our daily lives in America or our economy or our market, but it really is another marker on an extraordinarily populist trend. I think it started with Brexit, it continued with the election of Donald Trump in November 2016, then it's the five-star movement in Italy, a populist movement, which runs Italy, and which may well break up the European Union. And now, Brazil, it's the largest country in Latin America, 210 million Brazilians, the largest economy in Latin America, and it's going to be run by a conservative. This is quite something. So, it's in with the new, which seems to be populism, and out with the old. I'm sure you've reported it, Maria, but Angela Merkel, she's stepping down as the leader of her party, and will try to finish out her term as Chancellor of Germany. But whether she makes that or not is another story.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: She is out, and the populists in Brazil, Italy, America, elsewhere are in. What a trend.

BARTIROMO: I think -- I think it's also important to note that look what the alternative was, Stu, if you didn't vote in Brazil for Bolsonaro, you were voting for a socialist. So, once again, socialism was tested here.

VARNEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: We're looking at socialism sort of testing the waters across the world. People are not having it.

VARNEY: I wonder if it has an implication for our elections in eight days here. After all, the Democrats could be characterized as moving rapidly towards socialism, and President Trump, you could characterize him as a populist, if you like. That's the contest that we face in eight days' time. I just wonder if these worldwide trends will play out here, all over again.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It really seems like it is taking a hold across the world. In people -- in places you didn't expect like Italy, as you mentioned.

VARNEY: Oh, yes. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Stu, I know you're going to have a lot more in 10 minutes. We will see you then.

VARNEY: Yes, you will.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour 9:00 a.m. Eastern. Do not miss Stuart after MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

But first, there's this, hockey's new bet, details on the partnership between the New Jersey Devils and sports book operator William Hill. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. So, the New Jersey Devils getting into the legal gambling business. The NHL team making a multi-year deal with William Hill, to provide legalized gambling inside the Prudential Center, where they play. Joining us now is the CEO of William Hill U.S., Joe Asher. Joe, great to see you this morning, thanks so much for being here.

JOE ASHER, CEO, WILLIAM HILL U.S.: Hey, good morning. Nice to be with you.

BARTIROMO: So, congratulations.! This has been a long-term investment for William Hill, right?

ASHER: Well, it is. You know, we've been working towards the day when sports betting would become legal outside Nevada, and of course, that day came about five months ago when the Supreme Court overturned the federal law that had prevented that. And we are going to New Jersey pretty shortly thereafter, and recently announced the deal with the Devils and we're excited about it.

BARTIROMO: How much -- what kind of revenue are you talking about? What are you expecting in terms of the revenue that this will bring in?

ASHER: Well, across the country, I mean, you're looking at a market that the estimates are somewhere between 150 to $400 billion in the amount waged; figured about five or six percent that comes into revenue. So, it's a substantial market across the country, but of course, that's going to develop over a period of years, as states begin to legalize sports betting at the state level. You know, the Supreme Court basically turned the issue back to the states. States like Delaware, NEW Jersey, Mississippi, West Virginia got going quickly, and others are in the process, and it will develop over the next few years.

ROSCHELLE: Joe, Mitch Roschelle, good morning. Is the plan to expand across multiple states or is the plan in New Jersey to expand in the State of New Jersey?

ASHER: Well, our plan, of course, is to do both, Mitch. We've opened already at about a dozen locations in Mississippi, one in West Virginia. We're gearing up to get going in the not too distant future in Pennsylvania and in Rhode Island. And in New Jersey, we've just opened up our third retail location, but also in New Jersey, you can bet online by just downloading the app in the App Store, and you can bet from anywhere within the state, but you do have to be present within the State of New Jersey in that case to place your bets. You know, out here in Nevada, you've been able to bet on sports for decades, and you go into a casino, you sign up for your mobile account here in the State of Nevada and then you can bet anywhere within the state. Right now, we do about two-thirds of our business on mobile.

CARTER: So, you're just betting on the -- you know, you're at -- you're at a Devils game, you're just betting on that game or can you bet on all sports? Can you tell me a little bit about what it's like for them?

ASHER: Sure, you can bet -- you can bet on all sports within the -- within the State of New Jersey. Just like, you know, like I was at the Golden Knights game here in Las Vegas last night, really, really exciting game and they do a great job there, but not only were people betting on the Golden Knights game, they're betting on other hockey games that are going on. And now, of course, this is a busy time in the sporting calendar, last night, you had the last game of the World Series, basketball is getting going, we're in the middle of football season. So, there's a lot of -- there's a lot going on in the sporting calendar, which makes it a busy time of the year for us.

MCDOWELL: Joe, it's Dagen McDowell, name a sport that people might be surprised that people bet on so much. Like -- go ahead.

ASHER: No, I was going to say one of -- one of the big -- so, right now, we do about -- here in Nevada, we do about 37 percent of our business on what we call "in-play sports," or betting after the game has started. The number one sport for in-play by far is Major League Baseball, because the pace of the game is so conducive to it. But also, tennis is a -- is a big game that -- or a big sport for in-play wagering.

LEE: I would not expect tennis.

MCDOWELL: Yes. But people -- but again, it's -- because it's only two players, and/or in singles as two players, you can see if somebody looks fatigued.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Has gotten inside of their own head. And so, that's when you place in in-play bet maybe.

ASHER: Oh, you know, it's got --

MCDOWELL: (INAUDIBLE) from experience.

ASHER: Yes, you know, look, it allows you to take a bigger game then chop it down into a much shorter interval. So, for instance, in baseball, people like to bet will there be run scored in the next inning, yes or no. There's an actual break period in between innings, and we'll have people bet substantial sums of moment just on the next inning. You're taking a three-hour game, you're chopping it down to a 20-minute game. Tennis, same sort of thing, people will bet set by set or game by game, and you're taking a longer event and chopping it down into a much shorter event so people can make their bet, know whether they won or loss in a short period of time.

BARTIROMO: Very cool. Joe, great to have you, thanks so much. We'll be watching.

ASHER: All right. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Joe Asher, joining us there. Coming up, final thoughts from this all-star panel. Stay with us. Back in moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Final thoughts from this all-star panel. Lee Carter.

CARTER: I am looking forward to seeing how this week plays out in polling coming out to the midterms. I think that this week could surprise us all, and I think it's going to be a week that's going to lean Republican.

BARTIROMO: Really? All right.

CARTER: They do.

BARTIROMO: Eight days away from the Midterms. Mitch?

ROSCHELLE: The Fed's preferred inflation measure, PCE, just came out, it's still flat at two percent which is the Fed's target. So, let's see if the Fed holds off and doesn't continue to raise rates.

BARTIROMO: Why do we need a rate hike in December, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Right. Exactly.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Jon Hilsenrath has co-wrote an article in the Wall Street Journal that starts at "What If That Was as Good as It Gets In Terms of the Economy?" Well, we're looking at 3.1 percent wage growth coming up this Friday for last month, that would be the best in 9-1/2 years.

BARTIROMO: Which is good stuff.

MCDOWELL: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: All right. Have a great day, everybody. Go seize the day! Dagen McDowell, Mitch Roschelle, Lee Carter, great to see you. Let's get right to Stuart. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins right now. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: Good morning, Maria.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. Happy Monday to you. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Monday, October 29th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the button. It is looking like a pretty good start to trading this morning. Investors expected to start the new week on a strong note with Dow industrials up 126 points right now. That's a half of a percent higher.

The S&P is up almost one percent and the NASDAQ right now 71-point move higher is up better than one percent. This after the major indices capped off a volatility week last week with sharp declines on Friday. The Dow and the S&P 500 were down better than one percent on Friday. The NASDAQ down better than two percent on the heels of disappointing earnings from Amazon and Alphabet.

Global markets this morning have a firmer tone, European indices higher across the board, FT-100 up almost two percent, 125 points higher. CAC quarante in Paris is up almost one percent and the DAX Index in Germany up almost two percent, 198 points higher in Germany. In Asia overnight, markets finished mostly lower as you see there with the exception, Hong Kong. Shanghai Composite down sharply down better than two percent overnight.

Meanwhile, earnings certainly settling the tone from Wall Street this morning, several Dow components including Apple will be reporting their quarterly numbers this week. Investors are watching also G.E., the Wall Street Journal is reporting this morning that the company may be forced to cut its dividend again. One of the top stories in the Journal. Bit of a merger Monday on Wall Street to tell you about.

IBM is acquiring Red Hat for $33 billion. This is IBM's largest acquisition ever. Red Hat shares are up 52 percent on the news. IBM shares off of the lows down 3-1/4 percent. Coming up. How the deal will drive growth at the struggling technology companies coming up.

Breaking news overnight. A plane crashes shortly after in Indonesia. Nearly 200 were onboard. We have the very latest on the search effort happening right now.

And then honoring the victims of the Tree Of Life Synagogue shooting. Thousands of people filling the streets last night in Pittsburgh after President Trump condemned the attack on Saturday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF UNITED STATES: This evil anti-semitic attack is an assault on all of us, it's an assault on humanity. It will require all of us working together to extract the hateful poison of anti-semitism from our world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have the very latest coming up as the alleged shooter is set to appear in court today. All those stories coming up this Monday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, PwC Partner Mitch Roschelle and the president of Maslansky and Partners, Lee Carter. Good to see you. Great show so far guys.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here. Interesting times for sure.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Sure is.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: Yes. We've got -- we've got a lot of news and we've got an election in days.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Exactly. Well, and that could change a lot in terms of the agenda whether or not we see the economic agenda like another tax cut plan in place, Dagen, the rollback in regulations could be reversed. I don't know. I know the victory in the Senate side is going to be a big win for this president but certainly the House could do investigation after investigation of President Trump and his taxes and all that stuff.

That's what Jerry Nadler said as his priority if in fact he becomes the chairman of Oversight.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right. A lot -- you will see a lot of investigation that are for show and nothing else if the Democrats win the House, but there is still some races in the Senate that are extremely, extremely close. Watching Nevada for example, Dean Heller in Nevada, the seat is up for grabs in State of Arizona between Martha McSally and Kyrsten Sinema, that's really important to watch.

So there are look -- they - it looks like there are some real Republican wins afoot in the Senate but it's still going to be a nail-biter of what? Eight days from now.

CARTER: No question because you've seen the polling flip, you know, we were certain things are going one way and then the next week you see that they're, you know, that same candidate is seven points ahead of somebody that they were behind. So, they were going to really have to watch this case-by-case, moment-by-moment. And as things are happening, the way that the candidates, the way that the parties are reacting to these big events, like the events that happened this weekend.

The sad, tragic event at the Synagogue this weekend. The way that people react to this is going to dictate how people behave. It really is. And we want to heal right and we want to see healers. We don't want to see finger pointing. And so I think that real leadership is tested this week.

BARTIROMO: People are shutting down the hate, they don't want it anymore.

CARTER: No.

BARTIROMO: All of that coming up this hour. We got a big hour coming up. But first, this top story this hour and that is earning season is rolling on. Largely, we are in the second busiest week of the quarter in terms of earnings, Apple, Starbucks, General Electric, Facebook and ExxonMobil all reporting this week. That will set the tone for markets for sure. And we've got the October jobs' report coming out this Friday.

Expectations call for 190,000 jobs added to economy last month with the unemployment rate remaining steady at 3.7 percent. This would be for the month of October. Of course, November begins this week. Joining us now to talk all economics is JMP Securities President Mark Lehmann. And Mark, it is good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

MARK LEHMANN, PRESIDENT, JMP SECURITIES: Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Your thoughts on the backdrop for investing right now. Earnings and this upcoming jobs' report. What do you expect?

LEHMANN: Well, the market has been dominated by news not by earnings as of -- as October has progressed and obviously last week was not a great week for the markets and October has been awful month. I think we're seeing the futures point a little higher, I think, you know, the VIX trading as high as it has. I think -- I think we've seen the highs of the year and the lows of the year so far.

And I think we're going to recover a little bit here going into the election and going into the fourth quarter.

BARTIROMO: So more volatility is what you're --

(CROSSTALK)

LEHMANN: I think volatility is going to reign supreme. I think we have a headline-driven market to date. I think investors for the first time in a while are not reacting to some good numbers. And that tells me something. We're seeing IPO pricing denigrate, go down a little bit here. We've seen some deals that have been cut in half in size and the deals are not really popping anymore. We've seen some deals break price.

SurveyMonkey which is high profile IPO in the third quarter broke price and sees trading below their IPO price. Those are warnings science that will tell you, we'll see a little bit of a tampering of the market but I'm not worried about the market going in '19, I think better days are still ahead.

ROSCHELLE: The market shook off so much news all year. Every day there was something in the news cycle and the news cycle in the month of October if you look at it versus rest of the year isn't that much different but why is it that anything going on right now, the markets almost gone hyperbolic in terms of how they react to it.

LEHMANN: I think you said it well. I think we shook off a lot of bad news, and I think we shook off a lot of fear, let's use the China tensions that we've seen through the year and that continues to be in our backdrop and I think nobody expects that to end quickly and I think the specter of more tariffs and more back-and-forth is in front of us. I think there is also a question about the tax cuts and results on earnings.

What that means for comparisons going into '19, we have great comparisons 18 over 17, one of the comparisons looking at '19. And I just think more of more of that has grown into the market specter and that specter now is a little bit more cautious.

MCDOWELL: You have a major overreaction by investors to a little sliver of bad news. We've been talking about sales missing expectations for a revenue missing expectations for weeks now, but if you look at Amazon and the Wall Street Journal points this out today, that on Thursday evening, it posted a record -- a firm with a record third-quarter profit, right? It was 11 times more the profit was than the period a year earlier.

But it sales came up a little bit shorter of expectations. There were concerns about the forecast for the holiday season. But shares fell almost eight percent on Friday and that S&P was only down 1.7 percent. Amazon stock is down 18 percent so far in the month October. That seems like an overreaction.

BARTIROMO: But is it enough big since?

MCDOWELL: It is but -- and their concern is evaluation is what happens to stocks that people deem earlier over value. But that seems like a bit much, doesn't it?

LEHMANN: (INAUDIBLE) Saturday night is of exact same thing. So, what I'll -- what I'll tell you is --

MCDOWELL: And he is a farmer.

(CROSSTALK)

LEHMANN: No, listen. You're correct. And I think that's what happens when markets are tense and we have a very, very tense market. Stocks down 20 percent or $200 billion from its peak which is kind of an inspiring number. But you're right. People are a little bit nervous. I think the guidance that they give and they don't give long range guidance, they give very short guidance. Amazon is not one who guides two or three years in advance.

And I think they would loathe to go out on a limb here and say things are perfect. I don't think that make sense to them. I also think my money is on that company and another big tech company is who I really defining what's going on in this marketplace. Look at how much Red Hat just got acquired for because if they want to compete with Amazon web services, does that Amazon web services is worth 30 percent more than it was worth two days ago?

BARTIROMO: Well, that is exactly. And when you start zeroing in where the growth is, part of the growth story in this economy is cloud computing. And that's what you've got going on this morning. IBM acquiring software and services company Red Hat for $33 billion. Huge premium, stock is up 50 percent. It's part of this efforts to boost the could computing services which Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison told us about last week.

He emphasized the importance of cloud technology in the future.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY ELLISON, CO-FOUNDER, ORACLE: I think computing, I think computing -- cloud computing is going to -- you know, all these data centers that people have been building are going to gradually wither away and we're going to have a small number of these huge cloud networks. And because every other network looks like that, you know, people don't generate their own electricity.

People don't have wells for their own water. OK. In a few cases they do, but in the most case, we use the networks to buy electricity, the network to buy water, we're going to use network to buy computing and business applications and information. This is going to be on handful of clouds and most of the data is going to be in the Oracle database.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So, Mark, we know this cloud computing is one of the growth spots. You just said something interesting about IPOs, a lot of these companies that wanted to go public are the pulling back, lowering the pricing, one broke price. urn:contentItem:5RXP-0RF1-F021-62YB-00000-00Hated by Left and Right, only a free-market in data will save Big Tech from the coming storm2018-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:26ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY INTELLIGENCEVersion:1Hated by Left and Right, only a free-market in data will save Big Tech from the coming stormBy Allister Heath

For such a clever and connected industry, tech firms have proven hopeless at cultivating genuine friendships. They are increasingly hated by all sides of the political spectrum, and so the only question now is how severe the backlash will be, not whether it will happen.

The Left hate the size and profits of Big Tech,  want it to pay more in tax, are upset at its employment practices, and are incensed at what they believe, with limited evidence, was its role in Donald Trump's victory. The Right resent how Twitter is dominated by an elite that is hostile to capitalism, conservatism and Brexit, are angry at the technology establishment's Left-wing politics, and hate the industry's cultural conformity. Libertarians, who ordinarily have great respect for entrepreneurs,  are terrified about the abolition of privacy, the rise of a surveillance society, and the fact that data could easily fall into the wrong, authoritarian hands; hawks are concerned that mass automation means the West is exposing itself to devastating Russian or Chinese cyber-attacks.

In other words, nobody is happy, except for, by and large, consumers, who continue to lap it all up, buying from Amazon or signing up to Netflix in droves.  But as Sadiq Khan's attack on Uber reminds us, consumers are never a powerful enough constituency when all other groups want to target an industry. We are about to witness an avalanche of crude antitrust attacks, based on obsolete economic ideas, much higher taxes, often on revenues rather than profits, an economically stupid approach, and a generalised legislative onslaught. Some of this will help; but much will do more harm than good, and merely slow innovation. The Brussels-led assault on Microsoft in the 2000s proved the uselessness of this approach: regulators chased the wrong issues, not realising that another new technology - the internet - would make Microsoft's power over the desktop irrelevant.

.html-embed.component .quote.component{margin-left:0}.html-embed.component .quote.component .component-content{margin-right:16px}.quote__source, .quote__author {white-space: normal;}@media only screen and (min-width:730px){.html-embed.component .quote.component{margin-left:-60.83px}.html-embed.component .quote.component .quote__content:before{margin-left:-12px;padding-right:1px}}@media only screen and (min-width:1008px){.html-embed.component .quote.component{margin-left:-82.33px}}We need to create a real free-market in data: we need more and better capitalism, not less. We must empower individuals, not bureaucrats, by changing the rules of the game

There is a better way, and that is to apply intelligent centre-Right thinking to reforming tech. We need to create a real free-market in data: we need more and better capitalism, not less. We must empower individuals, not bureaucrats, by changing the rules of the game. History should be our guide.

Progress through the ages has come from extending, refining and spreading property rights to as many people as possible. Instead of tribal chiefs, Kings, the Church or a few noble families owning all of the land, the dispersion of property over the centuries helped create the conditions for an explosion in economic growth, liberalism and democracy.

As ideas became more important, we extended ownership to intellectual property, incentivising inventions and creativity. We are now at another turning point: we live in a data society and yet haven't started to think about who should own it. Should information about people - what they eat, where they drive, how they vote - be treated as "unowned", in what John Locke described as the state of nature, ready to be homesteaded by the big tech firms in return for better services or "free" apps? Or is such an approach an outrage akin to the imperialism of yore, when Westerners seized resources that should have been owned by local populations, and employed them as a consolation prize?

Facebook and Cambridge Analytica | The story so far

If the answer is the latter, the good news is that economists are working on solutions. Luigi Zingales and Guy Rolnik of the University of Chicago, for example, want to make it easier for new social networks to be created, and for users to switch, by changing the ownership of the data and social relationships contained in people's accounts. In the early days of the mobile phone, numbers were owned by providers, and it was hard for customers to shift to a competitor. They would have to inform all of their contacts of their new number, cumbersome for individuals and lethal for businesses.

All of this changed with mobile phone portability, when consumers were given ownership of their numbers. Our notion of property rights was upgraded: our mobile number is now part of our identity. Zingales and Rolnilk similarly want to reallocate the ownership of people's "social graph" - our networks and data, including pictures - from Facebook, Twitter or Microsoft's LinkedIn to the individual user. Our digital relationships would be ours, just like our homes, our postal addresses and our phone numbers.

.html-embed.component .quote.component{margin-left:0}.html-embed.component .quote.component .component-content{margin-right:16px}.quote__source, .quote__author {white-space: normal;}@media only screen and (min-width:730px){.html-embed.component .quote.component{margin-left:-60.83px}.html-embed.component .quote.component .quote__content:before{margin-left:-12px;padding-right:1px}}@media only screen and (min-width:1008px){.html-embed.component .quote.component{margin-left:-82.33px}}The tech world is in crisis, but the answer isn't more taxes, government meddling and socialism

Social media companies would become like telecom operators: users would no longer be locked in, forced either to sign up to whatever terms and conditions are imposed by the company or to quit altogether. It would radically constrain corporate power while avoiding the madness of nationalisation or forcible break-ups.

In a separate paper, economists, including Imanol Ibarra and Jaron Lanier, argue that user data is typically treated as capital, entirely created by and thus owned by firms from observing willing individuals who have signed away their rights to privacy. Yet this "neglects users' role in creating data", they explain, reducing incentives for consumers to help produce more of it, and fuelling mistrust. The solution? Classify data at least partly as the product of labour - in other words, make it part-owned by consumers. Data is a collaboration: without consumers, there wouldn't be any, and ditto without the tech firms.

Gaspard Koenig, of French think-tank Génération Libre, goes further still. He believes individuals should own all of the data they disclose about themselves, not the big tech firms that collate and distill it. He wants to give users a choice: they could refuse to hand over any data and instead be asked to pay a fee to use formerly free software, such as an email account; or they could rent their data, in exchange for a regular payment; or go the whole hog and sell it, for a bigger sum. A real market would be created - rather than an automatic trade of data for a free service - and a meaningful price for information would emerge.

The tech world is in crisis, but the answer isn't more taxes, government meddling and socialism. It's to create a free-market in data by making us own all of the information that we disclose, and by allowing us to choose whether we want to hand it over to companies and at what price. Radical? Of course, but the alternative - a Corbyn-style neutering of the tech industry - doesn't bear thinking about.

The Alliance for Interactive, Seasonal, and Location-based Entertainment sent letters to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin , House Speaker Nancy Pelosi , House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy , Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell , Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and more than two dozen other lawmakers making the case that the “industry has been unable to benefit from PPP in any meaningful way” and asking for changes. — The Paycheck Protection Program’s rules allow seasonal employers the option to use any 12-week period between May 1, 2019, and Sept. 15, 2019, when determining the maximum loan amounts for which they’re eligible. That’s a problem for haunted houses because their business doesn’t pick up until the fall. “I don’t know if folks imagined that the Covid crisis would extend this long” when the rules were written, said Aaron Cutler , one of the lobbyists representing the coalition. The lobbyists are pushing to get the changes included in any extension of the loan program and might expand the effort to include holiday-season businesses as well. FORMER MCCONNELL AIDE STARTS HIS OWN FIRM: Brian Forest , a former chief speechwriter for Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell , has started his own communications firm, Arboreal Communications . (“Arboreal” is a nod to his last name.) He’ll consult on messaging and write for trade groups, nonprofits and companies. Forest was previously the National Association of Manufacturers ’ director of strategic messaging and before that spent several years on the Hill working for McConnell as well as former Sen. Jon Kyl (R-Ariz.). The firm is a one-man shop for now but Forest said he’s looking to hire. Good afternoon, and welcome to PI. Tips [email protected] . Twitter: @theodoricmeyer . A message from Facebook: Facebook launches new Voting Information Center. Facebook is building the largest voter information effort in US history, starting with the new Voting Information Center, where you can find the latest resources about voting in the 2020 election. Our goal is to help register 4 million voters. Explore our new Voting Information Center now. ADMINISTRATION INDICATES U.S. COMPANIES CAN KEEP USING WECHAT IN CHINA: “The Trump administration is signaling that U.S. companies can continue to use the WeChat messaging app in China, according to several people familiar with the matter, two weeks after President Donald Trump ordered a U.S. ban on the Chinese-owned service,” Bloomberg News ’ Jennifer Jacobs , Shelly Banjo , Saleha Mohsin , Jenny Leonard and Naomi Nix report. — “The administration is still working through the technical implications of how to enforce such a partial ban on the app, which is owned by Tencent Holdings Ltd. , one of China’s biggest companies. A key question is whether the White House would allow Apple Inc. and Alphabet Inc. ’s Google to carry the app in its global app stores outside of the U.S., according to the people, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The intention is to prohibit any downloads or updates of the WeChat app in U.S. app stores, two of the people said. U.S. companies with China operations such as Starbucks Corp. could still advertise and process transactions with Chinese consumers via the app, they said.” WHO KAMALA HARRIS KNOWS IN SILICON VALLEY: The New York Times ’ Daisuke Wakabayashi , Stephanie Saul and Ken Vogel take a closer look at Kamala Harris ’ relationship with Silicon Valley , including her personal ties to the industry. “ Lartease Tiffith left his position as a senior counsel in Ms. Harris’s Senate office in late 2018 and became an in-house lobbyist for Amazon , focusing on privacy and security issues. Rebecca Prozan , who ran Ms. Harris’s first campaign for district attorney in San Francisco, is a top government affairs official for Google in California. Tony West , Ms. Harris’s brother-in-law and a former Justice Department official, is the chief legal officer for Uber .” — “‘There are familial connections and a level of mutual affection with Silicon Valley that goes above and beyond the fact that she is a San Francisco politician,’ said Jeff Hauser , executive director of the Revolving Door Project , a left-leaning watchdog group that has criticized Ms. Harris’s ties to Big Tech and other corporate interests.” (PI noted Tiffith’s role at Amazon last week in a roundup of former Harris aides on K Street.) ZUCKERBERG TESTIFIED BEFORE FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION: Mark Zuckerberg , Facebook ’s chief executive, “ testified this week at a Federal Trade Commission investigative hearing as part of the agency’s antitrust investigation into the social network, according to three people familiar with the case,” POLITICO ’s Leah Nylen and Betsy Woodruff Swan report. “FTC staff often interview witnesses under oath as part of their investigations in a process similar to a deposition and nearly always in cases they expect to lead to a lawsuit.” — “The people, who spoke on condition of anonymity because of the confidential nature of the probe, said the step doesn’t necessarily signal that the agency will ultimately pursue an antitrust lawsuit. Nevertheless, the testimony, conducted under oath and remotely over the course of two days this week, could be used to help the FTC and state attorneys general build a case against the social network.” REGIONAL AIRLINES STILL WAITING ON CORONAVIRUS RELIEF: “The Treasury Department's process for getting emergency loans out to small air carriers and others has been so shambolic that many companies are struggling to stay afloat as they await relief , as others go out of business,” POLITICO ’s Tanya Snyder reports. “After initially applying for a loan program for air carriers and other eligible businesses , in July — more than three months after many companies had applied for relief — aviation applicants were informed that they needed first to apply to the Main Street lending program, a general loan fund aimed at providing support for small and mid-sized businesses.” — "Since the CARES Act was signed into law, three regional airlines have ceased operation — Compass Airlines , Trans States Airlines and RavnAir Group — and ExpressJet is winding down by the end of the year. Other small air carriers and providers are still waiting, hemorrhaging money and trying to survive.” Jobs Report — Boeing is reshuffling its communications team, tapping Gordon Johndroe , a former White House spokesperson in President George W. Bush ’s administration, as vice president of global media and public affairs. Bradley Akubuiro is now the company’s chief spokesperson and senior director of global media relations and Betsy Andres Stewart is senior director of global public affairs communications. — The financial technology company Plaid has hired Meredith Fuchs to lead its legal and risk teams, per POLITICO ’s Morning Tech. She was previously Capital One ’s senior vice president and chief counsel for regulatory advisory. urn:contentItem:60M8-DXW1-DYRK-H00Y-00000-00Havas Media Is the First Agency to Join Prebid2020-08-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:26ZLexisNexisNEWSTAGHavas Media Is the First Agency to Join PrebidAndrew Blustein

Marketers will now have a larger voice in Prebid, a coalition of ad-tech companies that standardizes programmatic monetization.

Havas Media Group is the first media agency to join the coalition’s ranks. Prebid is mostly made up of sell-side ad-tech companies and publishers, so adding a buy-side member can help guide the design and implementation of new products, said Prebid chair Tom Kershaw.

“If Havas can help us get to something that’s real and actionable that a buyer can really use easily, that’d be a huge gain for the industry,” said Kershaw, who is also chief technology officer at Magnite, a supply-side platform. 

Prebid has bolstered its ranks lately, as independent ad-tech and publishers look to stay competitive with walled gardens. Index Exchange, an SSP, joined the group in July, and The Trade Desk became the first demand-side platform to join the group last November. 

There are multiple product management committees (PMC) within Prebid that focus on building standards in specific areas such as mobile, video and identity, which is a new group within Prebid that’s developing ways to implement alternatives to third-party cookies. 

Buyers will also have their own PMC to discuss and work on their own initiatives, which can ultimately be brought to the Prebid board for further support and development. Andrew Goode, evp, head of biddable media at Havas North America, said two main focuses will be around standardizing transparency and identity. 

Goode said there’s a loss of granularity as information gets passed along the digital advertising supply chain, making it hard for marketers to track the effectiveness of campaigns, so joining Prebid can help start a conversation to resolve that. 

“We need an ID that can pass all the way through,” Goode said. “How do we make sure that there is a clear tunnel, or a clear view from advertiser to publisher?”

Last year, Havas Media Group slashed the number of supply-side platforms it worked with down to seven for failing to provide the required levels of transparency.

Havas joining Prebid doesn’t mean the agency will direct more spend through the group’s header bidding tool and away from Google and Amazon’s products. Goode said it’s important to maintain an “agnostic” approach.

“We’re looking for the best, most meaningful routes to market, wherever they might be,” he said. “It’s more a question of, ‘How do we raise the standards across the board, rather than favoring one over the other?'”

There is increasing collaboration within the industry to build new standards as both regulators and Big Tech make it harder to track people online and ultimately serve targeted ads. 

The Trade Desk is in the process of building an open-source ID to replace third-party cookies. Meanwhile, six major trade bodies and five major brands are among a host of stakeholders in the The Partnership for Responsible Addressable Media, a new group looking to maintain targeted advertising.

Goode hopes other holding companies join Prebid to help push the digital ad industry forward in a serious time of change.

“Given that transparency and identity are two such big topics at the moment—there are decisions being made and there are ideas being spread—I think it’d be a missed opportunity if other holding companies are not participating and joining the conversation,” he said.

urn:contentItem:5Y6D-PYG1-F03R-N4F3-00000-00Have a Speech License? UK Watchdog Ofcom to Police Social Media2020-02-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:26ZLexisNexisHave a Speech License? UK Watchdog Ofcom to Police Social MediaAlexander Hall

Feb 12, 2020( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/ Delivered by Newstex) The British government may be free from Europe thanks to Brexit, but it appears to be sliding into authoritarianism as it drafts regulations to crack down on freedom of speech.Ofcom, the United Kingdom's media watchdog, according to Forbes' Feb. 12 coverage[1], 'is to be given the power to regulate social media companies, holding them to account for harmful content.'The UK has already reportedly threatened to begin jailing tech executives[2] for not policing their own platforms enough. An April press release[3] had established an Orwellian 'duty of care,' which requires 'companies to take reasonable steps to keep their users safe and tackle illegal and harmful activity on their services.'

Forbes wrote that Digital media and culture secretary Nicky Morgan is introducing measures based on a government white paper[4] launched in April last year. The 'duty of care' concept is mentioned in its pages[5] no less than 53 times.This 'Online Harms White Paper[6],' which was first released last April, also includes references to a similar German regulation 'Network Enforcement Act ('NetzDG'),' which can fine social media companies for up to 50 million Euros for failing to remove hate speech in compliance with German laws.One revealing admission made by this government document is that it describes 'online hate' as being targeted at groups 'including ethnic minorities and women.'It specifically cited the growing use of artificial intelligence ('AI') in moderating platforms, which seems to reflect a pattern with the British government. One such project, 'HateLab,'[7] funded by the Obama-era government and United Kingdom, uses artificial intelligence to scan users' social media for 'grossly offensive' anti-PC speech and attempted to predict when people will commit 'hate crime[s].' In short, the AI was meant to scan social media history for 'pre-crime' purposes.Morgan, quoted by Forbes, said she espoused "We will give the regulator the powers it needs to lead the fight for an internet that remains vibrant and open but with the protections, accountability and transparency people deserve."The 'Internet Association' was critical of the legislation, and represents the interests of Facebook, Reddit, Twitter, Amazon and Google. The more conservative Tory Party under prime minister Boris Johnson, which helped bring about Brexit, said, 'We will legislate to make the UK the safest place in the world to be online — protecting children from online abuse and harms, protecting the most vulnerable from accessing harmful content, and ensuring there is no safe space for terrorists to hide online,' according to the Jerusalem Post[9].Even the Northern Irish DUP's Carla Lockhart has condemned[10] 'anonymous accounts.' She commented: 'For too long the world of social media has been like an online Wild West, with no regard for what little rules exist.' She remarked that 'A token slap on the wrist will not be enough to protect users,' and said that going forward, 'it is vital that regulators are empowered with the ability to impose serious fines and penalties on social media companies."Perhaps American tech companies should honor their home country, and acknowledge that an internet of the 'Wild West' is ultimately what is best for liberty. Feb 12, 2020( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/Delivered by Newstex) The British government may be free from Europe thanks to Brexit, but it appears to be sliding into authoritarianism as it drafts regulations to crack down on freedom of speech.Ofcom, the United Kingdom's media watchdog, according to Forbes' Feb. 12 coverage[1], 'is to be given the power to regulate social media companies, holding them to account for harmful content.'The UK has already reportedly threatened to begin jailing tech executives[2] for not policing their own platforms enough. An April press release[3] had established an Orwellian 'duty of care,' which requires 'companies to take reasonable steps to keep their users safe and tackle illegal and harmful activity on their services.'

Forbes wrote that Digital media and culture secretary Nicky Morgan is introducing measures based on a government white paper[4] launched in April last year. The 'duty of care' concept is mentioned in its pages[5] no less than 53 times.This 'Online Harms White Paper[6],' which was first released last April, also includes references to a similar German regulation 'Network Enforcement Act ('NetzDG'),' which can fine social media companies for up to 50 million Euros for failing to remove hate speech in compliance with German laws.One revealing admission made by this government document is that it describes 'online hate' as being targeted at groups 'including ethnic minorities and women.'It specifically cited the growing use of artificial intelligence ('AI') in moderating platforms, which seems to reflect a pattern with the British government. One such project, 'HateLab,'[7] funded by the Obama-era government and United Kingdom, uses artificial intelligence to scan users' social media for 'grossly offensive' anti-PC speech and attempted to predict when people will commit 'hate crime[s].' In short, the AI was meant to scan social media history for 'pre-crime' purposes.Morgan, quoted by Forbes, said she espoused "We will give the regulator the powers it needs to lead the fight for an internet that remains vibrant and open but with the protections, accountability and transparency people deserve."The 'Internet Association' was critical of the legislation, and represents the interests of Facebook, Reddit, Twitter, Amazon and Google. She commented: 'For too long the world of social media has been like an online Wild West, with no regard for what little rules exist.' She remarked that 'A token slap on the wrist will not be enough to protect users,' and said that going forward, 'it is vital that regulators are empowered with the ability to impose serious fines and penalties on social media companies."Perhaps American tech companies should honor their home country, and acknowledge that an internet of the 'Wild West' is ultimately what is best for liberty. urn:contentItem:5S22-DDS1-DY9P-N1D5-00000-00Have FAANGS lost their bite in tech crash?;The soaraway stocks of Silicon Valley are under pressure to justify their power and responsibility,2018-04-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:26ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 48,49Have FAANGS lost their bite in tech crash?The soaraway stocks of Silicon Valley are under pressure to justify their power and responsibility,James Ashton

A changing of the guard took place on Wall Street nearly seven years ago when Apple surpassed the market value of Exxon Mobilto become America's most valuable public company.

Technology had led the way before, during IBM's heyday in the 1980s, but this switch would usher in a new era. After swapping the crown between themselves, Apple pulled away. Today it is worth more than two and a half times Exxon, whose capitalisation has changed little since 2011. Nor is it alone. The Google-owning Alphabet, Amazon and Microsoft are all valued at least twice the price of the energy company.

Consumer technology has not only changed lives, it has powered the share portfolios of millions of investors. But, given the regulatory and political storms that have blown up in the past three weeks, is Wall Street's love affair with the technology titans drawing to a close? The S&P 500 index of leading US shares has risen in value by two thirds over the past five years, powered by large technology companies. The FTSE 100 has mustered a 13 per cent gain over the same period.

Despite fears of a bubble, "big tech" has been a runaway success that top investors are loath to bet against. The fund managers who traded the steady earnings and generous dividends of Exxon and its old-world peers for technology shares will be forever grateful. Even in the last quarter of 2017, when many might have thought that stocks had become too expensive, the canny veteran Warren Buffett increased his holding in Apple by 24 per cent.

But something is changing again. Big tech is being forced to grow up. Confirmation on Wednesday that up to 87 million people may have had personal information taken from Facebook - and that data on most of its two billion users could have been improperly accessed - suggests that the events of recent weeks are only the beginning.

Since it emerged that Cambridge Analytica, the data firm, had gathered millions of Facebook profiles to influence voter choice, shares in Facebook have dropped by 14 per cent, while Alphabet is 9 per cent lower, Amazon is down 8 per cent and Apple is 3 per cent off. So much for the so-called FAANGs: angry investors' teeth marks are showing on the big beasts of Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Alphabet's Google. The worst-performing tech stock, though - and President Trump's favourite method of communication - has been Twitter, whose shares have tumbled by 20 per cent.

Next week, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's chief executive, will be questioned twice, by committees of first the US Senate and then the House of Representatives. Apologies for mistakes are unlikely to head off a watershed for how those that profit from the exploitation of personal data protect customers.

Thus far, regulatory scrutiny of Big Tech has not equated to investor pain. An investigation into Googleby the European Commission - which fined the company £2.2 billion last year for abusing its dominance of the search engine market - has not affected its share price performance. However, the biggest threat may come from within. From Standard Oil to AT&T, the United States has not been afraid to take its dominant companies to task. In the White House, there is a president spoiling for a fight. Mr Trump has Amazon in his sights, tweeting on Monday: "Only fools, or worse, are saying that our money losing Post Office makes money with Amazon. THEY LOSE A FORTUNE, and this will be changed."

Regulators are troubled by the size of these corporations and what that means for society, be it Amazon's impact on America's deserted shopping malls, or the vast wealth it has created for Jeff Bezos, its founder, enabling him to acquire The Washington Post.

Tech giants also face a fiscal threat. One solution gaining traction in Europe to raise more money from Big Tech is to tax sales in the locations where customers buy goods instead of trying to track profits across borders. Experienced technology investors think that what is happening is a necessary part of maturing for these relatively young firms.

"Tech has become a part of everyday life," says Saul Klein, whose venture capital firm Local Globe has backed start-ups. "This means we will continue to see amazing companies emerge, but it also means these companies will necessarily face more scrutiny, from markets, regulators and consumers alike."

Mr Klein thinks that Googleand Facebook have more to lose than Apple and Amazon if governments clamp down on how customer data is used. Yet he also points to strong investor appetite for new firms, such as Dropbox and Spotify. The latter, a Swedish music streaming service, had a strong start as a publicly listed company this week. Its shares dipped in first-day trading, but had opened at $165.90, sharply higher than the $132 guide price set for the stock. Its $26 billion market value is not bad for a company that made a $461 million loss last year. Perhaps not everything investors have taken for granted about the tech world will change overnight.

Regulators ride in to call halt to 'days of Wild West'

According to Matt Hancock, "the days of an unregulated Wild West are over" (Callum Jones writes). The lawmen are riding into town and, for the culture secretary, their arrival is long overdue.

The marshalls and sheriffs in this case are governments and regulators; in their sights, a motley crew of social networks failing to take responsibility for illegal content, search engines promoting their own services in results and corporate heavyweights arranging "sweetheart" tax deals.

The likes of Facebook and Twitter may twitch at talk of legislative action, but the first shots have already been fired. In January Germany introduced laws aimed squarely at such companies. Social networks may now be fined up to (EURO)50 million if they persistently leave illegal posts, including hate speech, terrorist material and child sex abuse, online for longer than 24 hours after they have been reported.

Yet more worrying for the sharpshooters of Silicon Valley are the bigger guns aimed at their pockets. Googleis appealing against a (EURO)2.4 billion fine imposed by the European Commission last year for abusing the market dominance of its search engine to promote its online shopping service. In 2016, Brussels ordered Apple to pay (EURO)13 billion in back taxes to Ireland over what it claimed was illegal state aid. Facebook has been fined (EURO)110 million for misleading officials over its acquisition of the Whatsapp messaging service. Now Washington is following suit, with politicians taking Facebook to task over its handling of millions of users' data and an irate President Trump lambasting Amazon.

Concern over greater regulation is said to have helped to persuade Peter Thiel, the venture capitalist and co-founder of Paypal, to withdraw from the technology industry this year. Such foresight from an early backer of Facebook and Space X is being praised by some of his peers.

'Politicians are taking Facebook to task over its handling of data'

urn:contentItem:5S22-6GC1-JCJY-G30R-00000-00Have FAANGS lost their bite in tech crash?;The soaraway stocks of Silicon Valley are under pressure to justify their power and responsibility2018-04-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:26ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:2Have FAANGS lost their bite in tech crash?The soaraway stocks of Silicon Valley are under pressure to justify their power and responsibilityJames Ashton

A changing of the guard took place on Wall Street nearly seven years ago when Apple surpassed the market value of Exxon Mobilto become America's most valuable public company.

Technology had led the way before, during IBM's heyday in the 1980s, but this switch would usher in a new era. After swapping the crown between themselves, Apple pulled away. Today it is worth more than two and a half times Exxon, whose capitalisation has changed little since 2011. Nor is it alone. The Google-owning Alphabet, Amazon and Microsoft are all valued at least twice the price of the energy company.

Consumer technology has not only changed lives, it has powered the share portfolios of millions of investors. But, given the regulatory and political storms that have blown up in the past three weeks, is Wall Street's love affair with the technology titans drawing to a close?

The S&P 500 index of leading US shares has risen in value by two thirds over the past five years, powered by large technology companies. The FTSE 100 has mustered a 13 per cent gain over the same period.

Despite fears of a bubble, "big tech" has been a runaway success that top investors are loath to bet against. The fund managers who traded the steady earnings and generous dividends of Exxon and its old-world peers for technology shares will be forever grateful. Even in the last quarter of 2017, when many might have thought that stocks had become too expensive, the canny veteran Warren Buffett increased his holding in Apple by 24 per cent.

But something is changing again. Big tech is being forced to grow up. Confirmation on Wednesday that up to 87 million people may have had personal information taken from Facebook - and that data on most of its two billion users could have been improperly accessed - suggests that the events of recent weeks are only the beginning.

Since it emerged that Cambridge Analytica, the data firm, had gathered millions of Facebook profiles to influence voter choice, shares in Facebook have dropped by 14 per cent, while Alphabet is 9 per cent lower, Amazon is down 8 per cent and Apple is 3 per cent off. So much for the so-called FAANGs: angry investors' teeth marks are showing on the big beasts of Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Alphabet's Google. The worst-performing tech stock, though - and President Trump's favourite method of communication - has been Twitter, whose shares have tumbled by 20 per cent.

Next week, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's chief executive, will be questioned twice, by committees of first the US Senate and then the House of Representatives. Apologies for mistakes are unlikely to head off a watershed for how those that profit from the exploitation of personal data protect customers.

Thus far, regulatory scrutiny of Big Tech has not equated to investor pain. An investigation into Googleby the European Commission - which fined the company £2.2 billion last year for abusing its dominance of the search engine market - has not affected its share price performance. However, the biggest threat may come from within. From Standard Oil to AT&T, the United States has not been afraid to take its dominant companies to task. In the White House, there is a president spoiling for a fight. Mr Trump has Amazon in his sights, tweeting on Monday: "Only fools, or worse, are saying that our money losing Post Office makes money with Amazon. THEY LOSE A FORTUNE, and this will be changed."

Regulators are troubled by the size of these corporations and what that means for society, be it Amazon's impact on America's deserted shopping malls, or the vast wealth it has created for Jeff Bezos, its founder, enabling him to acquire The Washington Post.

Tech giants also face a fiscal threat. One solution gaining traction in Europe to raise more money from Big Tech is to tax sales in the locations where customers buy goods instead of trying to track profits across borders. Experienced technology investors think that what is happening is a necessary part of maturing for these relatively young firms.

"Tech has become a part of everyday life," says Saul Klein, whose venture capital firm Local Globe has backed start-ups. "This means we will continue to see amazing companies emerge, but it also means these companies will necessarily face more scrutiny, from markets, regulators and consumers alike."

Mr Klein thinks that Googleand Facebook have more to lose than Apple and Amazon if governments clamp down on how customer data is used. Yet he also points to strong investor appetite for new firms, such as Dropbox and Spotify. The latter, a Swedish music streaming service, had a strong start as a publicly listed company this week. Its shares dipped in first-day trading, but had opened at $165.90, sharply higher than the $132 guide price set for the stock. Its $26 billion market value is not bad for a company that made a $461 million loss last year. Perhaps not everything investors have taken for granted about the tech world will change overnight.Regulators ride in to call halt to 'days of Wild West'According to Matt Hancock, "the days of an unregulated Wild West are over" (Callum Jones writes). The lawmen are riding into town and, for the culture secretary, their arrival is long overdue.

The marshalls and sheriffs in this case are governments and regulators; in their sights, a motley crew of social networks failing to take responsibility for illegal content, search engines promoting their own services in results and corporate heavyweights arranging "sweetheart" tax deals.

The likes of Facebook and Twitter may twitch at talk of legislative action, but the first shots have already been fired. In January Germany introduced laws aimed squarely at such companies. Social networks may now be fined up to (EURO)50 million if they persistently leave illegal posts, including hate speech, terrorist material and child sex abuse, online for longer than 24 hours after they have been reported.

Yet more worrying for the sharpshooters of Silicon Valley are the bigger guns aimed at their pockets. Googleis appealing against a (EURO)2.4 billion fine imposed by the European Commission last year for abusing the market dominance of its search engine to promote its online shopping service. In 2016, Brussels ordered Apple to pay (EURO)13 billion in back taxes to Ireland over what it claimed was illegal state aid. Facebook has been fined (EURO)110 million for misleading officials over its acquisition of the Whatsapp messaging service. Now Washington is following suit, with politicians taking Facebook to task over its handling of millions of users' data and an irate President Trump lambasting Amazon.

Concern over greater regulation is said to have helped to persuade Peter Thiel, the venture capitalist and co-founder of Paypal, to withdraw from the technology industry this year. Such foresight from an early backer of Facebook and Space X is being praised by some of his peers.

urn:contentItem:5S22-DDS1-DY9P-N119-00000-00Have FAANGS lost their bite in tech crash?;The soaraway stocks of Silicon Valley are under pressure to justify their power and responsibility,2018-04-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:26ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 42,43Have FAANGS lost their bite in tech crash?The soaraway stocks of Silicon Valley are under pressure to justify their power and responsibility,James Ashton

Achanging of the guard took place on Wall Street nearly seven years ago when Apple surpassed the market value of Exxon Mobilto become America's most valuable public company.

Technology had led the way before, during IBM's heyday in the 1980s, but this switch would usher in a new era. After swapping the crown between themselves, Apple pulled away. Today it is worth more than two and a half times Exxon, whose capitalisation has changed little since 2011. Nor is it alone. The Google-owning Alphabet, Amazon and Microsoft are all valued at least twice the price of the energy company.

Consumer technology has not only changed lives, it has powered the share portfolios of millions of investors. But, given the regulatory and political storms that have blown up in the past three weeks, is Wall Street's love affair with the technology titans drawing to a close? The S&P 500 index of leading US shares has risen in value by two thirds over the past five years, powered by large technology companies. The FTSE 100 has mustered a 13 per cent gain over the same period.

Despite fears of a bubble, "big tech" has been a runaway success that top investors are loath to bet against. The fund managers who traded the steady earnings and generous dividends of Exxon and its old-world peers for technology shares will be forever grateful. Even in the last quarter of 2017, when many might have thought that stocks had become too expensive, the canny veteran Warren Buffett increased his holding in Apple by 24 per cent.

But something is changing again. Big tech is being forced to grow up. Confirmation on Wednesday that up to 87 million people may have had personal information taken from Facebook - and that data on most of its two billion users could have been improperly accessed - suggests that the events of recent weeks are only the beginning.

Since it emerged that Cambridge Analytica, the data firm, had gathered millions of Facebook profiles to influence voter choice, shares in Facebook have dropped by 14 per cent, while Alphabet is 9 per cent lower, Amazon is down 8 per cent and Apple is 3 per cent off. So much for the so-called FAANGs: angry investors' teeth marks are showing on the big beasts of Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Alphabet's Google. The worst-performing tech stock, though - and President Trump's favourite method of communication - has been Twitter, whose shares have tumbled by 20 per cent.

Next week, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's chief executive, will be questioned twice, by committees of first the US Senate and then the House of Representatives. Apologies for mistakes are unlikely to head off a watershed for how those that profit from the exploitation of personal data protect customers.

Thus far, regulatory scrutiny of Big Tech has not equated to investor pain. An investigation into Googleby the European Commission - which fined the company £2.2 billion last year for abusing its dominance of the search engine market - has not affected its share price performance. However, the biggest threat may come from within. From Standard Oil to AT&T, the United States has not been afraid to take its dominant companies to task. In the White House, there is a president spoiling for a fight. Mr Trump has Amazon in his sights, tweeting on Monday: "Only fools, or worse, are saying that our money losing Post Office makes money with Amazon. THEY LOSE A FORTUNE, and this will be changed."

Regulators are troubled by the size of these corporations and what that means for society, be it Amazon's impact on America's deserted shopping malls, or the vast wealth it has created for Jeff Bezos, its founder, enabling him to acquire The Washington Post.

Tech giants also face a fiscal threat. One solution gaining traction in Europe to raise more money from Big Tech is to tax sales in the locations where customers buy goods instead of trying to track profits across borders. Experienced technology investors think that what is happening is a necessary part of maturing for these relatively young firms.

"Tech has become a part of everyday life," says Saul Klein, whose venture capital firm Local Globe has backed start-ups. "This means we will continue to see amazing companies emerge, but it also means these companies will necessarily face more scrutiny, from markets, regulators and consumers alike."

Mr Klein thinks that Googleand Facebook have more to lose than Apple and Amazon if governments clamp down on how customer data is used. Yet he also points to strong investor appetite for new firms, such as Dropbox and Spotify. The latter, a Swedish music streaming service, had a strong start as a publicly listed company this week. Its shares dipped in first-day trading, but had opened at $165.90, sharply higher than the $132 guide price set for the stock. Its $26 billion market value is not bad for a company that made a $461 million loss last year. Perhaps not everything investors have taken for granted about the tech world will change overnight.

Regulators ride in to call halt to 'days of Wild West' According to Matt Hancock, "the days of an unregulated Wild West are over" (Callum Jones writes). The lawmen are riding into town and, for the culture secretary, their arrival is long overdue.

The marshalls and sheriffs in this case are governments and regulators; in their sights, a motley crew of social networks failing to take responsibility for illegal content, search engines promoting their own services in results and corporate heavyweights arranging "sweetheart" tax deals.

The likes of Facebook and Twitter may twitch at talk of legislative action, but the first shots have already been fired. In January Germany introduced laws aimed squarely at such companies. Social networks may now be fined up to (EURO)50 million if they persistently leave illegal posts, including hate speech, terrorist material and child sex abuse, online for longer than 24 hours after they have been reported.

Yet more worrying for the sharpshooters of Silicon Valley are the bigger guns aimed at their pockets. Googleis appealing against a (EURO)2.4 billion fine imposed by the European Commission last year for abusing the market dominance of its search engine to promote its online shopping service. In 2016, Brussels ordered Apple to pay (EURO)13 billion in back taxes to Ireland over what it claimed was illegal state aid. Facebook has been fined (EURO)110 million for misleading officials over its acquisition of the Whatsapp messaging service. Now Washington is following suit, with politicians taking Facebook to task over its handling of millions of users' data and an irate President Trump lambasting Amazon.

Concern over greater regulation is said to have helped to persuade Peter Thiel, the venture capitalist and co-founder of Paypal, to withdraw from the technology industry this year. Such foresight from an early backer of Facebook and Space X is being praised by some of his peers.

urn:contentItem:5WC3-Y6P1-JCNX-34FF-00000-00Have Tech Companies Become Too Powerful?2019-06-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:26ZLexisNexisHave Tech Companies Become Too Powerful?

Link to Story

The open internet has become a crucial part of our daily lives, delivering enormous benefits in different industries.
LONDON, UK, June 17, 2019 / EINPresswire.com / -- The open internet has become a crucial part of our daily lives, delivering enormous benefits in different industries. That includes massive investments, new online educational pathways, and a surge in economic opportunities. Nonetheless, there's growing evidence that shows a handful of gatekeepers are capturing control over key components of online content, communications, and commerce.



To ensure that companies are not creating monopolies to control core forms of interpersonal and public communication to maximize profits, US regulators have launched an investigation on four tech giants. The regulators will document competition issues and anti-competitive conduct of Facebook, Amazon, Apple, and Google.Additionally, they'll assess whether the existing competition policies, antitrust laws, and enforcement levels are adequate to address the current issues.
Why Are Regulators Accusing Amazon, Google, Apple, And Facebook Of Being Monopolies?

•Amazon is currently the largest online store in the world, selling all sorts of consumer products. The store also runs a computing platform and produces TV shows/movies with Amazon Studios. Nonetheless, this tech giant has been accused of killing companies that use ideas similar to theirs.

•As the most used search engine, Google has significant control over the flow of information. The company also owns businesses in the video (Youtube), Navigation (Waze and Google Maps) and mobile operating systems (Android), to list a few. As such, the regulators believe Google gives its businesses special treatment, leading to unfair competition.

•Facebook has been blamed for spreading misleading information, helping to incite genocide, and violating user privacy. The company has over 2 billion users in all its platforms (Whatsapp, Facebook, and Instagram).

•With over a trillion dollar market value, Apple has been accused of driving up prices in their stores. The company is currently in a class-action lawsuit for these allegations.

How Did Big Tech Become So Powerful?
While the regulators have been busy with gambling platforms likeBetway , companies like Amazon and Google have been collecting a lot of information. These companies use that data to improve tools and services, allowing them to punish their competitors and keep growing. The network effect also plays a major role as most people join the network with the highest number of users.

Unlike betting companies such as Betway, most of these big tech companies acquire a huge amount of data by buying smaller companies. Experts believe that the Consumer Welfare Standard is to blame for this as the only consideration they put is to ensure the prices don't go up. However, big tech companies offer many free services for the standard to allow them to keep growing.

Under this view, a company like Google couldn't be stopped from acquiring Youtube as they don't compete. However, the standard fails to consider the driving force behind data-driven mergers and the company's access to the data or how it will help in maintaining its dominance.

As these big tech companies continue to grow, some scholars believe it's important to consider the non-price component of the competition such as privacy. That can be tricky to assess because such components are hard to determine, unlike price.RBN Media
